articles.title: 85 ‘active' lakes buried beneath Antarctica's ice discovered
articles.author: NEWS WIRE
articles.summary: Scientists have identified 85 previously unknown subglacial lakes in Antarctica's ice using a decade's worth of satellite data. The newfound lakes are 'active,' meaning they periodically drain and refill, changing size and shape over months and years. This activity affects the stability of glaciers and their movement over the Antarctic bedrock, which could impact global sea levels.

articles.title: Hope and community endures in the NC mountains a year after Helene
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: One year after Hurricane Helene in western North Carolina, people and businesses are working to get back on their feet one year after the disaster. The community is still recovering and rebuilding a year after Helene's landfall.      Â

articles.title: High surf could topple more Outer Banks homes
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Sea levels rise at an increasing rate and oceanfront homes in the Outer Banks face an increased risk of collapse due to high surf and oceanographic conditions. The homes in Buxton, North Carolina, are particularly at risk of being destroyed by the rising sea levels.

articles.title: Daylight Saving begins as clocks spring forward
articles.author: Times Team
articles.summary: Daylight Saving starts tomorrow Sunday morning, when clocks move forward an hour at 2am. New Zealand first introduced Daylight Saving time in 1927 and the Government last reviewed it in 2007. MetService meteorologist Silvia Martino says while daylight hours are getting longer, the sunrise will also shift for an hour. Fire and Emergency New Zealand urges people to check their smoke alarms.

articles.title: North Carolina residents brace for hurricane as they're still recovering from Hurricane Helene a year later
articles.author: Mike  Sullivan
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated North Carolina a year ago. Caroline Doyle and her family fled to her mother's home on a mountain during the storm. Robby Loven's home was nearly washed away and he had to move back in the first week of April. The campground near his home reopened May 1 but the full recovery effort didn't finish until last Monday.

articles.title: Ancient Australian tektites reveal new evidence of a giant asteroid impact
articles.author: Astronomy
articles.summary: Tiny pieces of glass found scattered across Australia have revealed evidence of a previously unknown giant asteroid impact. This discovery centers on a new book, "Ancient Australian Tektites: New Evidence of a Giant Asteroid Impact" by Andrew Keen and David Perry. It is published by Simon & Schuster.

articles.title: Who is responsible for building resilience?
articles.author: Kari
articles.summary: Building resilience is a shared responsibility. Communities, the private sector, youth, academia, regional and international development partners, and each Caribbean citizen have a crucial role to play. Youth and civil society organisations, faith-based groups, and indigenous communities play a vital role in preparedness, early warning systems, and post-disaster recovery. The private sector has a critical role because climate risk is business risk.

articles.title: All alone against China: warning for PM on Pacific
articles.author: Zac De Silva
articles.summary: Donald Trump's lack of interest in the Pacific means Australia may need to stand on its own against China, according to experts.    i.e. Australia may have to defend itself against China alone, experts warn. i.yours sincerely appreciate Donald Trump's interest.

articles.title: Tiny forests breathe life and hope into urban Australia
articles.author: Stephanie Gardiner
articles.summary: Anna Noon lives in one of Australia's fastest growing regional areas. She is dismayed that nature is being destroyed for sprawling housing developments.    for Anna Noon, Anna Noon is watching in despair as nature is destroyed for housing developments in her area.

articles.title: Is it worth moving to Tasmania for the cooler climate?
articles.author: Monty Jacka
articles.summary: There are about 13,000 people moving to Tasmania each year, but 15,000 leave for the mainland every year. The island state's maximum summer temperatures generally hover in the mid-20s. Mr Dover and his wife moved to Tasmania in 2019. Mr Kingston moved to the north-west coast of Tasmania in 2013. Mr Cheng and his partner moved six years ago.

articles.title: "This Volcano Could Kill Summer Forever": Scientists Warn Super Eruption Drops Earth's Temperature While Crops Die Worldwide In Months
articles.author: Hina Dinoo
articles.summary: Scientists warn of a potential super eruption that could affect global climates and economies. Sulfur dioxide emissions from eruptions can cause global cooling by reflecting sunlight away. A sudden temperature drop might disrupt agriculture and increase geopolitical tensions. Improved monitoring technologies are crucial for early detection and preparedness.

articles.title: "IT'S BEEN AN EMOTIONAL DAY": Taylor Co. remembers Helene impacts as recovery and repair continues
articles.author: Maya Sargent
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene made landfall in Taylor County one year ago. Many people are still rebuilding their homes. Kerri Bowen is the manager at Fiddler's Restaurant Bar and Grill. She tracks the hurricane season with daily check ins and keeping an eye on the tropics.

articles.title: Waves roll in from Atlantic as Humberto, other disturbance, gets closer to Florida, Georgia
articles.author: Jenese Harris
articles.summary: Waves are rolling in from the Atlantic Ocean as Humberto and another disturbance get closer to Florida and Georgia. Surfers are aware that bigger waves are coming this weekend. The biggest concern is coastal erosion. Emergency management is monitoring the situation, knowing that erosion could occur.

articles.title: Every stage of fossil fuel life cycle harms people & the environment: Report
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: A new report traces the life cycle of fossil fuels, from exploration and extraction to combustion and decommissioning. It finds stark consequences at each stage for the health of people and the planet alike.   It makes an important addition to the current understanding of fossil fuel's health impacts.

articles.title: Rising autumn heat raises health risks
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Rising autumn heat raises health risks. Summer-like temperatures extend into fall, so so does the risk of heat illness. The weather is expected to be warm and dry, but not too hot.    for the rest of the week. The forecast is not very accurate.

articles.title: World's oceans fail key planetary health check
articles.summary: A new report says ocean acidity has crossed a critical threshold for marine life. Boris Worm explains what it could mean for coastal communities, like Nova Scotia, in an interview with Amy Smith on CNN.com's "This is Life With Amy Smith" with Boris Worm.

articles.title: A simple action can help save birds flying over Oregon tonight
articles.author: Karly Imus
articles.summary: There are 4.6 million birds expected over Oregon on Friday, Sept. 26. The northwest corner of the state and a small swath in the north-central Oregon are under a High Alert. Fewer birds are expected on Saturday and Sunday nights: 3.7 million Saturday and 2.4 million Sunday.

articles.title: What is the Fujiwhara Effect?
articles.summary: Claire Fry explains the phenomenon and how it could impact the tropics on WFMY News 2's Claire Fry's news report.    Claire explains it could affect the weather in the Tropics as well as the Earth's climate.

articles.title: Friday, Sep 26 update: Latest on Category 3 Hurricane Humberto from the National Hurricane Center
articles.author: SUN HERALD BOT
articles.summary: Hurricane Humberto is a Category 3 storm with maximum sustained winds of 115 mph. It is 430 miles northeast of the Northern Leeward Islands and is moving to the west-northwest at 5 mph. Surf swells generated by the hurricane are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.

articles.title: Pinehurst neighbors file lawsuit after dam failure during Tropical Storm Chantal
articles.author: Carly Haynes
articles.summary: Bands of rain moved through Pinehurst on Friday, the same area that saw four-eight inches of precipitation in July. On July 6, a dam failed off of Knoll Road North, sending water from Longleaf Lake downstream into three homes, nearly claiming the lives of a Moore County family. On Tuesday, the families filed a lawsuit against U.S. Kids Golf, the company that owns the golf course where the dam stands. The lawsuit claims the company failed to make necessary changes to at least eight DEQ warnings over the past 10 years.

articles.title: Vancouver's warm nights may have set a new record
articles.summary: Vancouver hasn't had a temperature below 9°C for 126 nights in a row. It's the longest run of warm nights ever recorded in the city. September nights across the province have been unusually warm. 19 communities set new overnight minimum temperature records this month.

articles.title: Brunswick County Schools, College to close Monday due to weather threat
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Both Brunswick County Schools and Brunswick Community College will be closed on Monday due to the threat of severe weather. All campus locations, including the Dinah E. Gore Sports & Aquatics Complex and Odell Williamson Auditorium, will be shut down. Staff will receive additional details through their BCS email and supervisors. Families and employees will be notified no later than 5 p.m. Monday about plans for Tuesday.

articles.title: Guantánamo suspends agricultural fairs due to threat of tropical wave
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The Agricultural Fair in Guantánamo has been suspended due to the threat of heavy rains associated with a tropical wave approaching the eastern Caribbean. The collection and sale of agricultural products began on Friday afternoon at various markets in the city. Commercial establishments will offer an alternative menu featuring boiled dishes, stews, and croquettes.

articles.title: Failed NiMet forecast and looming food crisis in Kwara state
articles.author: Umar Bayo Abdulwahab
articles.summary: Farmers in Asa local government area of Kwara state are demanding explanations from the weather and climate agency over what they described as its failed 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) in the state. The drought occasioned by an unprecedented rainfall pattern destroyed several crops on thousands of cultivated hectares of farm land. Many of them are now counting their losses.

articles.title: Goa sees a rise in dry grass fires with over 1k cases in 2025
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: In the first eight months of this year, the number of dry grass fires in Goa has already touched the figure for the whole year in 2024. Last year, there were 2,411 such fires in the state, of which 32 affected wildlife sanctuaries. The forest department attributed the rise in wildfires in 2023 to unusual temperature spikes and scarce rainfall in the winter.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene 1 year later: GA agriculture impacts
articles.author: Kaylee Barbee
articles.summary: Helene devastated the southeast in 2024. At least $5.5 billion was lost in agricultural and timber industries in Georgia. 33% of the Georgia 2024 cotton crop has been destroyed. Georgia's timber crop was severely impacted, with a loss of $1.28 billion. Roughly ⅓ of the counties that produce the state's pecans were impacted by the storm, with an estimated 75% crop loss. The pecan industry will take several years to fully recover.

articles.title: Homes on the edge: In Outer Banks, faster pace of sea level rise increases risk
articles.author: Liz Mclaughlin
articles.summary: There are more than 100 miles of shoreline in Dare County, North Carolina, but there's a lot of erosion on the beaches. A dozen homes on the Outer Banks have collapsed in the past five years, including one in Buxton just last month. The erosion rate has been faster than it had been before.

articles.title: South Africa's agriculture poised for a strong 2025-26 season due to La Niña
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: There are early indications that 2025-26 may be another strong production season for South Africa's agriculture due to La Niña-induced rains. The International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) released its monthly update on September 19, indicating an increased possibility of LaNiña occurrence from October through to early next year.

articles.title: Fewer hailstorms but bigger hailstones: Climate change shifts Europe's severe weather risks
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Warming may lead to less frequent but bigger and more devastating hail storms, according to new research from the U.S. National Institute of Meteorology has shown.      Â   .   for confidential support call the National Institute on Meteorology on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Climate disasters mean oysters could be in short supply this Christmas
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Oysters will be smaller and more expensive on Christmas tables this year because of climate disasters in two states, which will make them scarcer and smaller this year.       in California and in New York. In the U.S. they will be more expensive.

articles.title: China Focus: China's fresh commitment hailed as major contribution to global climate action
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Xinhua reports that China is confronted with the urgent yet long-term challenge of climate change. China's government is concerned about the impact of climate changes on the environment.   Â      in China's environment is in decline.

articles.title: City-centric approaches to climate-related human mobility
articles.summary: As the impacts of climate change become more frequent and intense, people across the globe are forced to adapt. Much of this movement goes from rural to urban or peri-urban areas, which are perceived as desirable locations due to employment options, family connections, and other opportunities. Urban populations are rapidly growing, from 46.7% of the world's overall population in 2000 to 56% in 2020 and 60% in 2030. Climate change in urban settings has caused impacts on human health, livelihoods and key infrastructure. Cities sit at the nexus of mobility, adaptation, and loss and damage.

articles.title: Sarasota artist Skip Dyrda restores 'Tails from the Harbor' mural in Punta Gorda
articles.author: Tom Hall
articles.summary: Sarasota artist Skip Dyrda visited Punta Gorda last week to restore his 2019 mural, "Tails from the Harbor." The mural was damaged during Hurricane Milton. It is one of 32 murals the Punta  Gorda Historic Mural Society has installed since 1997. It measures 14 feet in height by 76 feet in length.

articles.title: Hottest Septembers in Georgia since 1895
articles.author: Stacker
articles.summary: 2022 will be the third hottest July since 1895 in the continental United States. 20 states saw one of their 10 hottest days in the same month. The year prior, July marked the hottest month on record worldwide, according to NOAA's data.

articles.title: Hottest Septembers in Idaho since 1895
articles.author: Stacker
articles.summary: 2022 will be the third hottest July since 1895 in the continental United States. 20 states saw one of their 10 hottest days in the same month. The year prior, July marked the hottest month on record worldwide.   Â   .

articles.title: Hottest Septembers in Arizona since 1895
articles.author: Stacker
articles.summary: 2022 will be the third hottest July since 1895 in the continental United States. 20 states saw one of their 10 hottest days in the same month. The year prior, July marked the hottest month on record worldwide, according to NOAA's data.

articles.title: Hottest Septembers in South Dakota since 1895
articles.author: Stacker
articles.summary: 2022 will be the third hottest July since 1895 in the continental United States. 20 states saw one of their 10 hottest days in the same month. The year prior, July marked the hottest month on record worldwide.   Â   .

articles.title: Hottest Septembers in Illinois since 1895
articles.author: Stacker
articles.summary: 2022 will be the third hottest July since 1895 in the continental United States. 20 states saw one of their 10 hottest days in the same month. The year prior, July marked the hottest month on record worldwide.   Â   .

articles.title: Report: Climate Change Alarms 78% of Moroccans, Only 18% Take Action
articles.author: Adil Faouzi
articles.summary: A new survey shows that most Moroccans are aware of climate change and environmental issues, but they do not engage in effective environmental initiatives. Only 18% of respondents participated in organized environmental activities over the past five years. The main obstacles cited were lack of nearby activities and time constraints.

articles.title: Mapped: Which U.S. Cities Saw Record-Breaking Temperatures in 2024?
articles.author: Julia Wendling
articles.summary: Eighty-two U.S. cities set new all-time temperature records in 2024. The data comes from the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information. The primary driver of global warming is human-induced climate change, fueled by the excessive burning of fossil fuels. The trend is likely to continue unless efforts are made to transition toward renewable energy and reduce overall consumption.

articles.title: A Hidden Mountain Valley Lost 72% of Its Bugs. That Shouldn't Be Possible.
articles.author: Elizabeth Rayne
articles.summary: Insect populations in a mountain valley in the Colorado Rockies are declining due to increasing summer temperatures. Keith Sockman, a biologist from UNC Chapel Hill, studied them for two decades and found a population decline of 72.4% from 2004 to 2024. He suspects climate change to be the cause.

articles.title: Aussie Data Shows Self-Serving Insurance Industry Reports of Climate Disasters Are Dead Wrong. There Is No Trend!
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: Insurance costs for natural disasters haven't increased in nearly 60 years in Australia. Population has grown from 11 million to 27 million, but there is no sign of any extra effect from climate change. Back in 1967 global carbon dioxide stood at 320ppm, now it's 425ppm.

articles.title: How the blue economy can break the cycle of poverty in Southeast Asia's coasts
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: The blue economy can combat multigenerational coastal poverty. Small-scale fishers and aquaculture workers remain largely excluded from the development process. Southeast Asian coastal residents are vulnerable to low income and unpredictable climate change, despite being situated next to rich marine resources.

articles.title: Study warns coral reefs will dramatically shrink as climate heats up
articles.author: Finya Swai
articles.summary: Coral reefs in Florida Keys and Gulf of Mexico are dying off faster than they can grow. The trend is expected to accelerate across much of the Caribbean. If the planet warms more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial temperatures, 99 percent of the reefs in the region will be in net erosion by 2100.

articles.title: A year after Hurricane Helene, many WNC farmers are still struggling to recover
articles.author: Giselle Thomas
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit Western North Carolina a year ago. Farmers are still dealing with the storm's lasting impacts. They are working to repair damaged infrastructure and adjust to declining hay production and eroded topsoil. North Carolina A&T's Cooperative Extension is providing education and assistance in rebuilding efforts.

articles.title: Novato: City Of Novato Asks The Public To Review Climate Change Readiness Plans
articles.author: Bay City News Service
articles.summary: The city of Novato is crafting new policies and programs to prepare for climate change. It is asking the public for feedback by Oct. 19. All cities must prepare a climate change plan by 2034. According to the draft plan, Hamilton and Bel Marin Keys are most vulnerable to sea level rise. The Novato Creek corridor, Ignacio and downtown areas are vulnerable to inland flooding. Indian Valley, Pacheco Valley and hillside neighborhoods could see increased risk of wildfires.

articles.title: One year after Hurricane Helene: Loss, resilience, renewal
articles.author: Joe Grandy
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated Washington County and its surrounding region one year ago. The storm caused a wall of water from the Nolichucky River and torrential rains.    It was a sight none of the residents will ever forget. It left a trail of devastation across Washington County.

articles.title: Sustainable Switch: Unpacking Trump's UN speech
articles.author: Sharon Kits Kimathi
articles.summary: Donald Trump is skeptical of global environmental initiatives and multilateral institutions. The last global scientific consensus on climate change was released in 2021 through the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The summer of 2024 was the hottest on record in Europe, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service. Trump's rhetoric against science, knowledge, environmental, social and governance (ESG) policies pose a larger threat.

articles.title: Storms on the radar? More than likely just 1.2 billion birds in flight for fall migration
articles.author: Brandi D. Addison
articles.summary: This time of year marks the peak of fall migration. Millions of birds are leaving northern breeding grounds for warmer southern wintering areas. Radar estimates suggest more than 1.2 billion birds took to the skies on Sept. 25 flying around 2,000 feet above the ground at 22 mph.

articles.title: Storms on the radar? It's actually just 1.2 billion birds in flight for fall migration
articles.author: Brandi D. Addison
articles.summary: Radar estimates suggest more than 1.2 billion birds took to the skies Sept. 25. It's the biggest night of migration yet recorded by BirdCast. This time of year marks the peak of fall migration. Millions of birds are leaving northern breeding grounds for warmer southern wintering areas.

articles.title: Atmospheric chaos has sent temperatures soaring in Antarctica
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Stratospheric temperatures in Antarctica are spiking, which could see strange weather unfold across the southern hemisphere in the coming months.    .   in this article we reported that Stratospheric Temperatures in Antarctica were spiking. In fact, they were decreasing.

articles.title: Transportation officials postpone parkway extension hearings
articles.author: Staff Report
articles.summary: The public hearings on the proposed Carolina Bays Parkway extension project have been postponed due to potential coastal storm impacts forecasted for North Carolina and South Carolina. The hearings were set to be held in Sunset Beach Monday and again Tuesday in Longs, S.C. They will be rescheduled for a later date.

articles.title: Parkway extension hearings postponed due to storm forecast
articles.author: Staff Report
articles.summary: Public hearings on the proposed Carolina Bays Parkway extension project have been postponed due to potential coastal storm impacts forecast for North Carolina and South Carolina. The hearings that were set to be held in Sunset Beach Monday and again Tuesday in Longs, South Carolina, will be rescheduled for a later date.

articles.title: Odisha Prepares for Impending Depression Over Bay of Bengal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A depression over the Bay of Bengal is expected to cross the coast of Odisha. The state is bracing for heavy rain. The Chief Minister held a crisis meeting to strategize for minimal damage. Special attention is being paid to the rivers and embankments. Emergency services are on high alert.

articles.title: Western NC family still seeks reassurance a year after unimaginable loss from Helene
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Helene: What We Lost, What We Found is a documentary about the devastation and resilience of Hurricane Helene in western North Carolina. Helene brought landslides that killed 13 people in the Fairview area. Eleven of those deaths were from the extended Craig family who settled in the small valley called Craigtown.

articles.title: How to manage climate change anxiety
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Thomas Doherty is the author of "Surviving Climate Anxiety". Doherty talks to CBS News about climate change anxiety and global warming.    iReport.com will have more on this topic later on CBS News. iReport will be back on air at 10.

articles.title: Youth Advisory Group on Climate Change speaks to leaders at UN general assembly
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: It's officially fall — so why does it still feel like summer?
articles.author: Liz Mclaughlin
articles.summary: Since 1970, the autumns in North Carolina have warmed by 3 degrees Fahrenheit. In Raleigh, the 85-degree threshold that once marked the transition from summer to fall now arrives about two weeks later than it did a half-century ago. Health officials have recorded more than 5,600 emergency department visits for heat-related illness since May 1,400 more than last year.

articles.title: New map illustrates NOAA's reach as Trump targets weather agency funding, research
articles.author: Elise Plunk
articles.summary: The Environmental Defense Fund has released an online tool that tracks 735 subagencies under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The agency provides daily weather forecasts and emergency alerts for extreme weather across the county. It also leads climate research, coastal restoration and fisheries monitoring work both within the agency and through local partnerships. Louisiana has more than a dozen NOAA offices.

articles.title: ETSU highlights Helene recovery efforts over past year
articles.author: Brandon Paykamian
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated parts of Western North Carolina, Southwest Virginia and Northeast Tennessee in September 2024. Volunteers from East Tennessee State University have been engaged in long-term recovery efforts since then.    in the past year they've remained engaged in recovery efforts.

articles.title: Op-Ed: Climate Positivity—It's What We Need
articles.author: Melissa Scott
articles.summary: Melissa Scott quit her job in climate change research after 15 years to spend more time with her son, Hudson. On Friday, September 27, 2024, Hurricane Helene hit Cattail Creek near Burnsville, NC. Two waterfalls next to their home looked like brown tsunamis. The raging water burst the bridge near them into tiny Lincoln Log pieces. The creek's raging water swept up over the banks, took a home off its foundation, and sent it toward a neighbor. Bruce, a neighbor, drowned in his bedroom after over a million gallons of water ran through his home. Melissa's husband, Sean, had to hike 11 miles to get to them.

articles.title: My Aon Talk and Australia Papers
articles.author: Roger Pielke Jr
articles.summary: THB Australia Week continues and will spill over into next week. Today, he shares slides from his presentation at the 2025 Aon Australia Hazards conference. His talk used the just-released Australian National Climate Risk Assessment as a case study in the challenges of knowing what is true and what is not in the context of the intense politicization of climate science and assessment.

articles.title: Gaza aid flotilla man from Poole 'undeterred by drone threat'
articles.author: Marcus White
articles.summary: There were 11 explosions on Tuesday night involving boats in the Global Sumud Flotilla in the Mediterranean. Louie Findlater, from Poole, Dorset, took time off work to join the flotilla. Neil Duncan-Jordan is among more than 80 MPs who have written to the government to urge it to protect UK citizens on board from Israeli attacks.

articles.title: WATCH: Mom's viral video of a 2. 5-metre python sunbathing on her roof
articles.author: Zama Ndosi Cele
articles.summary: A video of a 2.5-metre python sunbathing on the roof of Ash BG's house in Sydney has gone viral, amassing over 1.3 million views. The video has sparked a flurry of reactions from viewers, many expressing their apprehension about living in Australia.

articles.title: Feeding the Future: Nature-based Solutions for Resilient Food Systems
articles.author: Observer Research Foundation
articles.summary: Rising challenges from climate change, environmental degradation, and biodiversity loss are exerting strain on global food systems, undermining their ability to ensure food security for a projected 9.1 billion people by 2050. According to estimates, crop yields in West and East Africa are projected to decline by 2.9 percent by 2030 and up to 18 percent by 2050, underscoring the urgency for adaptive policies and resilient food system strategies. IUCN defines Nature-based Solutions (NbS) as 'actions to protect, conserve, restore, sustainably use and manage natural or modified terrestrial, freshwater, coastal and marine ecosystems'

articles.title: Hurricane Helene One Year Later
articles.author: Amy Lynn
articles.summary: There are several events to mark the one year anniversary of Hurricane Helene. Leslie Dalton with the United Way Of East Tennessee Highlands tells WJHL about the events and opportunities to volunteer. To find out more, visit www.UnitedWayetnh.org.

articles.title: Finding the Spark: Greeks Demand Probe Into Causes of Wildfires
articles.author: Balkan Insight
articles.summary: After another destructive fire season, experts and activists say Greece will not be able to prevent them unless it investigates what's starting the blazes and finds out who's to blame for them.   Â      in Greece, experts say.

articles.title: Climate change talk for Burgess Hill u3a members
articles.author: SUSAN MOODY
articles.summary: Bill Avenell, a retired geography teacher, will speak to Burgess Hill u3a on climate change at Cyprus Hall on Monday 6th October at 10:30 am. The talk is free and open to non-U3 members. The doors open at 9:45 am and refreshments are available.

articles.title: Public hearings on Carolina Bays Parkway Extension postponed due to potential storm threat
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Carolina Bays Parkway Extension public hearings are postponed due to forecasted weather early next week. The hearings were originally scheduled for Monday at the Sea Trail Convention Center in Sunset Beach and Tuesday at the North Strand Recreation Center in Longs, South Carolina. The proposed multi-lane freeway is designed to improve traffic flow, mobility, and regional connectivity.

articles.title: Humberto becomes a hurricane; chances of second system increase
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Humberto is now a hurricane. Development chances are increasing for another disturbance in the Atlantic. The disturbance is located 465 miles northeast of the Northern Leeward Islands. There is significant uncertainty in the long-range track and intensity. The chance of wind, rainfall, and storm surge impacts for a portion of the southeast U.S. coast during the next several days is increasing.

articles.title: "This Heat Killed Six Football Fields Of Ice": Swedish Glaciers Gone In One Summer While Earth's Temperature Breaks All Records
articles.author: Rosemary Potter
articles.summary: Eight glaciers in the Kebnekaise mountain range in Swedish Lapland have disappeared due to rising temperatures. This year was recorded as the hottest ever by the World Meteorological Organization, driven by the extensive use of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution. The disappearance of the glaciers is a microcosm of the global environmental crisis. It underscores the need for comprehensive policies aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: How Earth's ‘Thermostat' Can Malfunction, Flipping Global Warming Into Ice-Age Level Cooling
articles.author: Studyfinds Analysis
articles.summary: New research shows that global warming events can trigger long-term cooling strong enough to resemble ice age conditions. Biological carbon burial in oceans can outpace rock weathering as a climate regulator. This mechanism may explain why major ice ages coincide with shifts in oxygen levels in Earth's past.

articles.title: Gardeners urged to leave one food item out for robins in autumn
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardeners are being urged to leave one type of food out for robins this autumn and winter in a bid to help these classic British favourites during the cooler autumn weather. Robins do not migrate south for winter, so gardeners should leave suet pellets, fat balls, fruits and berries in winter and leave mealworms and calcium worms.

articles.title: Chief Engineer Assures No Flood Threat to Odisha Despite IMD Red Warning
articles.author: Itishree Sethy
articles.summary: 20 gates of the Hirakud dam have been opened, releasing 5.78 lakh cusecs of water at Mundali as a precautionary measure. The India Meteorological Department has issued a red warning for southern districts and an orange warning for neighboring districts. The low-pressure system is expected to intensify into a depression within 24 hours.

articles.title: 400,000 evacuated, three dead as new storm batters Philippines
articles.author: Sharjah 24
articles.summary: Severe Tropical Storm Bualoi has killed three people in southern Luzon's Bicol region. In Masbate province, evacuees took cover under pews after the roof of a church used as a shelter was ripped apart. Around 400,000 people have been evacuated across affected areas. Super Typhoon Ragasa struck the country's far north earlier this week and killed at least nine people.

articles.title: No Threat Of Immediate Flood Despite Heavy Rain In State: Chief Engineer
articles.author: Ommcom News
articles.summary: 20 gates of the Hirakud dam have been opened, with 5.78 lakh cusecs of water flowing at Mundali. The India Meteorological Department has issued a red warning for southern districts and an orange warning for the neighbouring districts of South Odisha. The low-pressure system is expected to intensify into a depression within the next 24 hours.

articles.title: NHRC validates landmark report on climate change, human rights in Gambia
articles.summary: The NHRC has prioritised the advancement of economic, social, and environmental rights. The Commission conducted a five-day nationwide data collection exercise from 20th to 25th July 2025. The survey targeted communities most affected by climate change. The assessment aimed to amplify the voices of affected communities and engage policymakers in identifying policy gaps and strengthening the legal framework.

articles.title: Mayor Dons ‘Save South Coast Jobs' Sign at Aquaculture Conference in Response to Proposed Conservation Area
articles.author: Sara Strickland
articles.summary: Steve Crewe was at the Cold Harvest aquaculture conference in St. John's this week. Crewe is concerned about the potential impact of a proposed Marine Conservation Area that would cover an area greater than the size of Prince Edward Island. articles.title: The bold push to make one of Australia's most scenic walkways step free
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Disability advocates are calling for accessibility upgrades to a popular coastal walk that has been ravaged by recurring bad weather. The walk is popular with tourists and people with disabilities, but it's not accessible for the elderly and disabled due to weather conditions. The coastal walk has been badly affected by bad weather in the past.
